newsitem.title: MEXICO: Half a cheer for Mexico's petrochemical retreat.
newsitem.headline: Half a cheer for Mexico's petrochemical retreat.

text.p: Mexico's retreat on the privatization of state oil monopoly Pemex's secondary petrochemical units drew half a cheer Monday from traders and analysts, who said it was not clear the government would find any takers for a minority stake.

The Energy Ministry announced Sunday that instead of an outright sale of its petrochemical plants to foreign and Mexican firms it would create a series of subsidiaries, maintain a 51 percent stake in them and offer the remainder to private investors.

The move was widely seen as a compromise between the government's initial privatization plans -- backed by the United States and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) -- and the strong nationalist opposition from the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) and the leftist Democratic Revolution Party (PRD).
But it also raised questions about whether Pemex can raise enough capital through offering minority stakes, said Luis Acevedo, a columnist for El Financiero newspaper.
Acevedo said Pemex hoped to generate $5 billion from the petrochemical sales, a figure he called "without foundation" and moreover "a very small quantity for such a complex industry."

In a rare show of support for the government, the conservative National Action Party (PAN) backed the plan as a means to generate the capital needed to improve the largely outdated petrochemical technology in Mexico.

One PAN legislator said her party is likely to give the new plan a chance -- though the government's large majority in Congress means opposition opinions are largely irrelevant to legislative decisions.

"In some form or other, (the new strategy) is strengthening these plants that are in poor conditions," PAN congresswoman Teresa Gomez Mont told Reuters. "This is not too far divorced from what the PAN has proposed."
But the representative of one company that had planned to bid on petrochemical businesses told a Mexico City newspaper he was unimpressed with the government's plan.
"We can't go just half-way, so we'll have to move forward in other areas (of privatization) like railroads," Roberto Rodriguez Puente, director of operations for Grupo Cydsa, told Reforma newspaper.
"With a (private) participation of only 49 percent, we'd have to think twice about it."

Reforma's main headline called the decision a "retreat" while its economic columnist Enrique Quintana said the new rules must allow stockholders to impose conditions on the use of their capital in order for the plan to work.
"It will be necessary for Pemex to define clearly the mechanisms," Quintana said. "If not, it is unlikely that anyone would accept the commitment of their capital in this partnership."
One Mexico City-based economist, however, thought the compromise was at least a step forward.

"It's better than nothing, which is what people were expecting, at least until after the (congressional) elections next year," Ann Ginsberg, an economist at Valores Finamex, told Reuters. "It's the best they could do because of the difficult political situation they were in," she said.

One Mexican equities trader said he expected the stock issue to be well-received by investors in general but doubted whether the companies interested in buying some of the petrochemical businesses would be interested in the new stock.
"There are similar precedents from other countries, so I think it could be well-accepted," the trader said. "But everything depends on the terms of the issue."
A spokesman for one company that planned to bid on part of the petrochemical business said his firm would wait for the terms of the stock issue before commenting publicly.
